moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. Bc4 f5 4. Nf3 Nf6: Here, white is prepared to launch an attack on the Kingside with his Queen, two minor pieces and his f pawn.  I'll try to fight him off...this is going to be messy...
moves.6... d5 7. Nxd5 Nxd5 8. Qh5+ g6 9. fxg6: How in the world do I defend against this? His pawn to g7 will win my Rook and the pawn will promote.
moves.9... Bxf2+: Sometimes the best defense is a good offense...
moves.10. Kxf2 Qf6+ 11. Kg1: Gotta move my King...I'm losing serious material here...
moves.11... Ke7 12. Nxh7 Qg7 13. Bxd5: Yep...serious material and my King is open..forward!
moves.13... Nd4 14. Qg5+ Kd6: A Queen trade on f6 would probably would have won him the game...
moves.15. Bf3: ???  Bishop to g7 would have been much better for White...
moves.16. gxh7 Qxg5 17. h8=Q Nxf3+: But getting some back...White's g pawn is pinned.
moves.20. Bxd2: ?? He should have retreated his Queen to defend.  My plan now is to force his King to a white square...then I can check him with the Bishop and attack his Queen at the same time with Rook...AKA discovered check....
moves.20... Qxd2+ 21. Kg3: I have to keep checking him so that his Queen has no opportunity to defend...eg. If I play Queen to e3 check he can block with his Queen...must avoid!
moves.24. Ke1 Qe3+: King to f1 allows mate...King to d1 is not any better really...hello white square!
moves.26. Qf3+: The only way out of check...
